I have a few Fiori elements apps that use event driven side effects as well as collaborative drafts. Both of these features are using websocket connection to receive changes from backend. All apps work fine when they are deployed to ABAP AS and accessed via Fiori launchpad hosted directly on ABAP AS.

What else needs to be set to enable ws connections from BTP down to backend system? What could be blocking the ws connections?

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Planned Independent Requirements for determining targ...
entry.content:
Good day @AngelT 

Thank you for your question

Based on your description and the screenshots you attached, the error message points to the fact that you ticked ‚ÄúUse PIRs‚Äù instead of Forecast. Which means when you run Rapid Replenishment with RF, the system searches for PIR quantities from your planning date onwards. If it does not find any PIRs in that time frame, then you get the error message you described.

In your described scenario, what happened was, your PIR quantities start only from later weeks, so if your planning date is earlier, the system finds no PIR at the beginning of the horizon and raises that error.

You can correct this in your system. To do this:

In Maintain PIRs, select the same product and plant you use in Replenishment Planning. Make sure your version is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù. Maintain PIR quantity starting in the current week and save.

Then in your replenishment Planning, you need to run it with same matching details. In Adapt Filter, activate and fill Plant, Product, MRP Type=RF. Optionally you can also activate MRP area if you used one in PIRs.


If you still get the PIR error, check Logs, verify the log shows which areas it searched for. Make sure those exact keys match what you maintained in your PIRs.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - SQL Views as SQL Script ‚Äì Automatic...
entry.content:
From a developer‚Äôs perspective, SAP Datasphere should explicitly support a Code-First modeling approach ‚Äî not as a replacement for the UI, but as a first-class, equal alternative.

I have only started working with SAP Datasphere since last week, and this was the very first limitation my colleague and I noticed. The inability to fully define models in code immediately stood out in our daily development work.

For professional developers, it is essential to be able to define models entirely in code. This includes the ability to declare a structured output schema directly in SQLScript, such as a header with column names, data types, and semantics (similar to RETURNS TABLE or declarative column definitions).
Today, this metadata must be maintained manually in the UI, which becomes extremely time-consuming and error-prone for complex or frequently changing queries.

A Code-First approach would provide significant advantages:

‚Ä¢ Versioning and Traceability
Fully declarative models can be cleanly versioned in Git, reviewed via diffs, and reproduced reliably. UI-managed metadata cannot offer the same level of transparency.

‚Ä¢ Maintainability and Scalability
Large SQL models with many columns are difficult to refactor and maintain through the UI. Code is inherently better suited for restructuring, reuse, and long-term maintenance.

‚Ä¢ Reduction of Manual Errors
Maintaining logic in SQL and semantics in the UI creates duplication and inconsistency. A declarative schema in code would establish a single source of truth.

‚Ä¢ Developer Adoption and Productivity
Many Datasphere users come from HANA, SQL, and data engineering backgrounds. A UI-only modeling approach creates friction and limits Datasphere‚Äôs adoption as a true enterprise-grade platform.

Importantly, Code-First does not exclude UI-First.
Business users can continue to benefit from graphical modeling, while developers gain the flexibility to define everything in code ‚Äî including structure, semantics, and output schema.

If SAP Datasphere aims to position itself as a modern, developer-friendly data platform, Code-First modeling is not a nice-to-have ‚Äî it is a necessity.

I strongly encourage SAP to consider this capability and to provide a clear roadmap in this direction.

entry.title: Re: How to work with retentions in SAP Business one - AR...
entry.content:
You're using a 2010 note.

Withholdings are defined in Management-Definitions-Finance-Taxes-Tax Withholding. Review the linked accounting accounts and Category, selecting Invoice and not Payment.

At the company level, go to Management-Definitions-Finance-General Ledger Account Determination and enable the tax withholding checkbox.

Then, in the IC (Income Tax) record, on the Taxes tab, enable the withholding you apply or that is applied to you.

Finally, you'll see its application reflected when you create an invoice.

entry.title: Implement code logic for batch determination in CO01 on 'Release Order' (S/4HANA)
entry.content:
Hi everybody,

I have this requiremet on CO01 batch determination that needs to switch between FEFO and FIFO strategies. I've tried to acomplish this by SPRO->Batch determination ->Strategies, but it does not give me exactly what I want even tho it gets close.

Explanation: 

1- We use FEFO when a material has VFDAT (yes, there may be cases where it doesn have it). 

2- IF theres more than 1 batch and both have the same VFDAT the system automatically gets the lowest batch number. This would be correct in most scenarios but not here. We can have highest batch number as the first produced and lowest batch number as most recently produced.

3- Only when this happens (they both have VFDAT and they both have the same VFDAT) we need to switch to FIFO strategy.

Through spro we can achieve an strict FIFO/FEFO logic, but not what I need (as far as I know). I've tried some user_exits to see if I can manipulate this batch determination on CO01 but I can't find the one to get the objetive.

I've tried:

- SE19 -> CL_RSH_WORKORDER_UPDATE -> Here I implemented some breakpoints on methods AT_SAVE / AT_RELEASE / INITIALIZE / IN_UPDATE /BEFORE_UPDATE but I think none of these works for me.
- SMOD -> PPCO0001 -> EXIT_SAPLCOBT_001 -> Here I tried the same, implemented some breakpoints and external breakpoints but it doesn't seem to stop.
- Tried SMOD -> PPCO0013/PPCO0021/PPCO0007 too but same as before, doesn't seem to stop.

Does anyone had a similar scenario to light me up?

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Record Voice in SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Using NativeScript Plugin (Android)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • SAP Mobile Services account

  • MDK project opened in Visual Studio Code

  • NativeScript CLI installed

  • Custom MDK client (mandatory for NativeScript plugins)

    Step 1: Install the NativeScript Audio Plugin

    Run the following command inside your .mdkproject folder:

     

    npm install @nativescript-community/audio

    Step 2: Update MDKProject.json

    Add the plugin under Externals, NSPlugins, and NPMPlugins

    { "AppDisplayName": "Audio Recorder MDK",
      "AppName": "AudioRecorderMDK",
      "AppVersion": "1.0.0",
      "BundleID": "com.sap.mdk.audiorecorder",
      "Externals": ["@nativescript-community/audio", "@nativescript-community/perms"],
      "NSPlugins": ["@nativescript-community/audio", "@nativescript-community/perms"],
      "NPMPlugins": ["@nativescript-community/audio", "@nativescript-community/perms"],
      "UrlScheme": "mdkclient"
    }

    Step 3: Update  settings.json

    Add the plugin to mdk.bundlerExternals in the settings.json file in Visual Studio Code. 

     

    "mdk.bundlerExternals": [
  "@nativescript-community/audio"
]

    Step 4: Create the Android Voice Recording Rule

    Create the rule file:

     

    /Rules/RecordAudioAndroid.js

    Behavior

    • First tap ‚Üí start recording

    • Second tap ‚Üí stop recording

    • Audio saved as .3gp

    • UI status updated using ClientData

      RecordAudioAndroid.js 

       
      import  { TNSRecorder } from "@nativescript-community/audio";
import { knownFolders } from "@nativescript/core";

let recorder;
let isRecording = false;

export default async function RecordAudioAndroid(context) {
    const pageProxy = context.getPageProxy();

    try {
        /* ---------- STOP RECORDING ---------- */
        if (isRecording && recorder) {
            await recorder.stop();
            recorder = null;
            isRecording = false;

            pageProxy.getClientData().AudioRecordStatus =
                "Recording completed";
            await pageProxy.redraw();
            return;
        }

        /* ---------- START RECORDING ---------- */
        if (!TNSRecorder.CAN_RECORD()) {
            throw new Error("Microphone not available");
        }

        recorder = new TNSRecorder();
        recorder.debug = true;

        const folder = knownFolders.documents();
        const filePath = `${folder.path}/audio_${Date.now()}.3gp`;

        pageProxy.getClientData().AudioRecordStatus =
            "Recording in progress... Tap again to stop";
        pageProxy.redraw();

        await recorder.start({
            filename: filePath,
            channels: 1,
            sampleRate: 16000,
            android: {
                source: 0,       // MIC
                audioEncoder: 3, // AAC
                outputFormat: 2
            }
        });

        isRecording = true;

    } catch (error) {
        recorder = null;
        isRecording = false;

        pageProxy.getClientData().AudioRecordStatus =
            "Recording failed";
        await pageProxy.redraw();
    }
}.  

      Note : If you want an uncompressed format, you can get a .wav file by following the below configuration:

      await recorder.start({
      filename: recordedFilePath,
      channels: 1,
      sampleRate: 16000,
      android: {
      source: 0, // MIC
      wavAudioFormat: 2 // PCM_16BIT
      }
      });

      Step 5: MDK Page Configuration

      The recording is triggered by tapping a microphone image.

      AudioPage.page

       
      {
  "_Type": "Page",
  "_Name": "AudioPage",
  "Controls": [
    {
      "_Type": "Control.Type.SectionedTable",
      "Sections": [
        {
          "_Type": "Section.Type.Image",
          "Image": "/AudioRecorderMDK/Images/Mic.png",
          "Width": 200,
          "Height": 200,
          "Alignment": "Center",
          "OnPress": "/AudioRecorderMDK/Rules/RecordAudioAndroid.js"
        },
        {
          "_Type": "Section.Type.KeyValue",
          "KeyAndValues": [
            {
              "_Type": "KeyValue.Type.Item",
              "Value": "{#Application/#ClientData/AudioRecordStatus}"
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

      Step 6: Android Permission

      Ensure the microphone permission exists in the custom MDK client. Add this in the AndroidManifest.xml found in the below path

      App_Resources_Merge/Android/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml 
       Add the below line in AndoidManifest.xml
      <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.RECORD_AUDIO" />

      The permission prompt is automatically shown when recording starts.

      Step 7: Run and Test

      Deploy your MDK app to your desired environment. 

      tns run android

      Step 8: Distribution

      A customized mobile development client is required for distributing this application on Android and iOS platforms. For more details on how to generate the customized MDK client refer to step 4 in the tutorial: Build Your Mobile Development Kit Client Using Cloud Build Service

      Conclusion

      Using the @nativescript-community/audio plugin, voice recording can be seamlessly integrated into SAP MDK applications on Android. The .3gp format ensures maximum compatibility and efficiency, making it ideal for enterprise mobile use cases such as inspections, voice notes, and field reporting.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Madrid 2026 - Apr 17, 2026
entry.content:
¬°Hola Madrid!

We are very excited to announce that the SAP Inside Track Madrid is back in 2026. It will take place next April 17, 2026 @ the EPAM Neoris AI Hub in Madrid, üá™üá∏. The space for the event is limited and we can only host 70 attendees. Make sure to RSVP fast!

An SAP Inside Track (SIT) is a local grassroots community event where SAP Community members come together to share knowledge about SAP related topics. The event is driven/organized by the community, everyone who is interested may participate. Everyone can benefit or contribute: act as presenter, take part in discussions, exchange information, realize networking or enjoy the social get-togethers in the evening.

You can check out all the details about the event in https://sitmadrid.com. Also, if you are interested in speaking üó£Ô∏è at the event? Let us know by submitting your proposal here.

Come to learn and share your knowledge with your peers as well as make new friends in an informal atmosphere. SAP Inside Track events offer SAP Community provided sessions from SAP Experts and passionate SAP Community members.

We will also host an SAP CodeJam the day before (Apr 16, 2026) - üá™üá∏ TBA (Madrid, Spain). You can register for the event here - TBA.

Special thanks to our event sponsors: EPAM Neoris, SAP, SAP Press, and Sulzer.

The space for the event is limited and we can only host 70 attendees. First come first serve. We will manage a waitlist so even if we've reached 70 RSVPs please still register as some might not be able to make it to the event.

See you in April 2026!

entry.title: Re: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello,

very good recap on this functionality.

They way it works is by using a FM to calculate a column on an existing dataset.

If we consider other use cases that requires input parameters, for example:

- extract information from READ_TEXT FM.

- extract BOM for a set of products that is calculated in Datasphere.

Those use cases require something like "calling 10000 times the Odata service" each time with different parameters.

I can not find any solution at the moment for those, as Datasphere can not apply dynamically input parameters to a source.

Another one is:
- the source to be extracted is the output of an ABAP report.

Have you any hint on these cases?

Best regards,
Alberto

entry.title: SAP UX Q1/2026 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
entry.content:
This second post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations that become generally available with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release. Highlights are further AI-assisted features: for personalizing My Home, getting explanations for error messages, and Situation Handling recommendations. We also provide the often-requested capability to launch apps via transaction code or SAP Fiori ID, the new ‚Äúrequired reading‚Äù feature for news in My Home, and mobile phone optimization ‚Äì to name a few.

Users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can use Joule to access their data: via web browser on desktop, or mobile, via SAP Mobile Start, which also provides access to applications directly. Read about innovations for Joule and SAP Mobile Start in the first blog post introducing the series, and providing information about SAP Build Work Zone:

  • SAP UX Q1/2026 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Below, you will get an overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition UX innovations in these areas:

SAP Fiori launchpad
  o.  New shell bar now the default
  o.  Launch apps directly via Transaction Code / Fiori-ID
  o.  Making New Apps Available to Users
      -  Activating new apps, since now delivered inactive
      -  New Experience Switch
   o.  Further improvements for the launchpad
My Home
  o.  Manage News app now with ‚Äúmust be read‚Äù feature
  o.  Enhanced Personalization
  o.  AI-Assisted UX Features:
       -  AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications
       -  AI-Assisted Error Explanation
       -  AI-Assisted Situation Handling
SAP Fiori elements mobile phone optimization
UI Adaptation
Improvements in details

Beyond these, we have a number of interesting new UX innovations for beta testing and early adopters with the 2602 release. I plan to cover these in my next blog post in the next few days.

Many of the UX improvements in details are enabled by our UI framework (SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements) and hence also available to customers and partners developing their own applications. Note however that the enabled AI-assisted features are only available for extensions built directly on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.

Below you‚Äôll see AI innovations from our UX framework as well as some selected application highlights. You can get a more comprehensive overview of the latest AI innovations in these blog posts, which also include application specific examples:

  • Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release.
  • AI innovations highlights in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.
  • Artificial Intelligence in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad

Let‚Äôs look closer at these UX updates:

  • New shell bar now the default, with updated design of notifications and user menu.
  • Launch apps directly via Transaction Code / Fiori-ID.
  • Further improvements.

New shell bar now the default

We have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite. The new shell bar first became available as an opt-in choice for customers with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 as described in my blog post covering 2508. With the 2602 release, it is now activated by default.

Benefits of the New Shell Bar

The new shell bar has these benefits:

  • The product name is displayed prominently now to the right of the SAP logo. In this case the name is ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù.
  • Updated notifications design.
  • Updated user menu design.

Product Name Displayed

The immediately visible difference with the new shell bar is that the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 1. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

Figure 1: New shell bar, now activated by default. Alt Text: A screenshot of Manage Sales Orders app, with the shell header highlighted, looking as described in the text.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 2 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 

Figure 2: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 2  fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and provides simplier interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, as you can see in Figure 3 below. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

 Figure 3: Updated design of notifications. Alt Text: A short video showing the user selecting to display the list of notifications in the groups ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù and ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù. 

Recommendation: Check Test Automation and RPA

We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have, since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you access the user menu, for example to log off at the end of a test.

In case you need more time to do this, you can opt-out of the new shell bar for this release.You can switch it off via ‚ÄúActivate New Features‚Äù, Feature ‚Äú/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE‚Äù.

Important: do switch it back on before next upgrade! There is no opt-out planned from 2608 onwards.

Launch apps directly via Transaction Code

Customers have been requesting this for quite a while now, so I am happy to announce that with the 2602 release, users can launch applications directly via the transaction code (t-code).

This is particularly helpful for those users who have experience with older SAP ERP systems, such as SAP ECC (ERP Central Component), and are used to launching transactions by entering the ‚Äút-code‚Äù (transaction code) in the SAP GUI for Windows shell bar. To launch a transaction VA01 (Create sales order) in SAP GUI for Windows, users enter ‚Äú/nVA01‚Äù if they want it to open in the same window, and ‚Äú/oVA01‚Äù if they want it to open in a new window. Lower case ‚Äú/nva01‚Äù or ‚Äú/ova01‚Äù also works. Furthermore, users could go to the start page by entering ‚Äú/n‚Äù or ‚Äú/o‚Äù, opening it either in the same window or in a new window respectively.

We have implemented the same logic in the search field in the launchpad shell bar, but with ‚Äú/o‚Äù now creating a new browser tab rather than opening a new window.

We have also extended it, so that users can also enter the t-code after ‚Äú/n‚Äù or ‚Äú/o‚Äù. Figure 4 shows what it looks like, and Figure 5 shows a short video of it in action for an example using /nmm03 (Display Material) to open the classic UI and /nF217A (Customer ‚Äì 360 View) to open a Fiori app.

 

Figure 4: Launching a classic UI via the transaction code ‚Äúva01‚Äù. Alt Text: The shell header is shown, with the search field showing ‚ÄúAll‚Äù and the search term /nva01 entered.

 

Figure 5: Launching applications directly via transaction code. Alt Text: A short video showing the user entering /nmm03 and /nF217A as described in the text.

You can determine an application‚Äôs t-code via the About entry in the launchpad user menu. We have also assigned transaction codes to Fiori apps, they are often identical to the Fiori ID, but not always.

Read more about it in this blog post:

  • Navigate SAP Fiori launchpad with Ease: Launch Apps via Transaction Codes.

Making New Apps Available to Users

New apps for business users can help them work more effectively, and get their work done more easily ‚Äì but only if they actually use them! That means that they need to be activated and hence made available to users in the first place.

When one or more new applications are delivered that replace an existing application, users of the existing application need to be informed that a replacement is available to them. This is handled by the New Experience Switch. This is especially important if the existing application is about to be deprecated.

The next two sections cover these two topics in more detail: activating new apps, and the New Experience Switch.

Activating new apps, since now delivered inactive

With the 2602 release we no longer activate new apps automatically, so as not to disrupt existing users, as well as to ensure that users are not automatically granted authorizations that they should not have.

In order to activate an application, i.e. a Fiori app or a classic UI, the underlying IAM  (Identity and Application Management) apps of type ‚ÄúApp Authorization Variant‚Äù need to be activated. These particular IAM apps were introduced a while ago in order to allow finer-grained authorizations for applications.

For example, the My Inbox app has a standard view and an expert view. You will only be able to access the expert view if the corresponding IAM app for the expert view has been activated by your administrator. If your administrator has only activated the IAM app for the standard view, then you will be able to access the My Inbox app, but only its standard view.

Since new apps provided by SAP are no longer activated automatically, administrators need to activate the underlying IAM apps of type ‚ÄúApp Authorization Variant‚Äù. Only then will users be able to find the apps via the launchpad search or in the App Finder, see the corresponding tiles on pages in the launchpad, and assign them as favorites in My Home.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Work with IAM Apps (App Authorization Variants)
  • How to Activate or Deactivate IAM Apps (App Authorization Variants)

New Experience Switch

The New Experience Switch informs users that a replacement of the application that they have opened is available to them, and offers a toggle in the shell bar to directly switch to the new application. You can see what this looks like in the top left image in Figure 6.

If the existing, old version of the app is planned to be deprecated and removed in a future release beyond the next one, then the information icon in the shell bar next to the New Version toggle is replaced by a warning icon, as shown in the top right image in Figure 6.

Finally, if the existing, old version will be removed with the upgrade to the next release, an alert is shown instead of a warning, as shown in the bottom image in Figure 6.

Figure 6: New Experience Switch. Clockwise from top left: Information, Warning and Alert pop-overs. Alt Text: Three screenshots showing the respective popovers, each with a button ‚ÄúSwitch to New Version‚Äù. The first two include a carousel giving information about the benefits of the new version. The last one include in red ‚ÄúAugust 2025‚Äù as the month when the app is planned to be removed.

The three phases described above were introduced already with the 2508 release.

With the 2602 release, we also support cases where one application has multiple successors. Figure 7 shows an example.

Figure 7: New Experience Switch warning for an application with multiple successors. Alt Text: Screenshot showing the popover containing two cards, one for each of the specialized versions available as successors.

Also new with 2602 is the option for users to provide feedback when the open up the new version of an application (Figure 8). When they select this, a survey is opened with one page of questions about the new version of the app.

Figure 8: New Experience Switch welcome pop-over for new app, now with ‚ÄúProvide Feedback‚Äù button. Alt Text: Screenshot showing the pop-over, with a carousel giving information about the benefits of the new version.

To find out more, have a look at the documentation, or at the SAP note for the list of apps that currently have successors making use of the New Experience Switch:

  • Documentation: Switching to a New App Version
  • SAP Note 3545277 - New Experience Switch in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Overview of Apps

Further Improvements for the Launchpad

Enterprise Search Shows All Smart Business Tiles

Business users can now find all their Smart Business tiles (typically insight tiles with KPIs and/or mini charts) using enterprise search in the launchpad shellbar. Since users can define their own tiles via Smart Business, with specific filter values, this means that they can also find these personal tiles using search.

Did you know that enterprise search supports a number of search operators that you can use when searching for apps, or indeed when searching for business objects? Operators such as OR, *, - and ‚Äú‚Äù.

You can also further filter search results, export them, share them or save the search as a tile. Find out more in the documentation:

  • Searching and Launching Apps or Business Objects.

Administrators can Upload and Download Spaces

In the Manage Launchpad Spaces app of the SAP Fiori launchpad, administrators can download existing spaces together with their assigned pages and upload them again to another system.

This enables you to transfer spaces and their assigned pages to other systems, for example, when you can't use transports, meaning that you can improve productivity and consistency across systems. Find out more:

  • Documentation: Downloading and Uploading Spaces

 

My Home

We continue to enhance My Home to make it even more popular with users. In this release, we have:

  • Manage News app now with ‚Äúmust be read‚Äù feature
  • Enhanced Personalization
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications
    (this is covered in the next section AI-Assisted UX Innovations)

We are also providing the feature AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home for beta-testing, which I will showcase in part 3 in this series of blog posts.

Manage News App now with ‚ÄúMust be Read‚Äù Feature

News articles containing essential company information can now be designated as required reading. All users must acknowledge that they have read and understood the content.

The main benefits of this feature are:

  • Strengthens accountability: When reading is mandatory, employees can be held accountable for understanding essential information. This practice helps ensure compliance with legal, safety, and policy-related requirements.
  • Ensures consistent knowledge across the organization: All employees receive the same information, minimizing knowledge gaps and miscommunication.
  • Enhances change management : During periods of transition‚Äîsuch as the introduction of new policies or process changes‚Äîrequired reading ensures that all employees understand the reasons behind and the impacts of those changes.

Figure 9 shows what this looks like for a user: a required reading pop-over appears on their screen. The article has also been flagged as ‚ÄúContaining Critical News‚Äù.

Figure 9: An example of a news article that is required reading. Alt Text: A screenshot of My Home with a pop-over ‚ÄúRequired Reading‚Äù that is also highlighted with ‚ÄúContains Critical News‚Äù. The news article has an image at the top, followed by text showing the first part of the article. The ‚ÄúDone‚Äù button is greyed out, the ‚ÄúRemind me later‚Äù button is visible.

Figure 10 below shows the Manage News app, with the toggles Critical and the new Required Reading one.

Figure 10: The Manage News app has a toggle to mark articles as ‚ÄúRequired Reading‚Äù. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News app with the toggles set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù, and some news text in the Description field.

Enhanced Personalization

A great strength of My Home is the degree to which users can personalize it to suit their needs. We have now enhanced personalization further by letting users control the visibility of News and Pages separately within the News and Pages section of My Home.

If they are not so interested in news, they can choose to hide it, with the additional benefit of having all the pages only take up one row of vertical space rather than two, as shown in Figure 11. Figure 12shows how users can do the personalization.

Note that even with the news hidden, they will still receive required reading: when they log on, the required reading appears as a pop-over that can only be closed by confirming that one has read and understood the content.

Alternatively, users can decide to only show news and not pages. They can of course also decide to show both news and pages, as before, or hide both.

Figure 11: My Home with enhanced personalization, showing News deselected and Pages selected. Alt Text: A screenshot of My Home, with eight cards in one row in the Pages section, below the ToDos section showing one situation and the Apps section.

Figure 12: My Home Settings pop-over with the new selectors for News and Pages within the News and Pages section. Alt Text: A screenshot showing the Layout part of My Home Settings, where users can select or deselect sections. For the News and Pages section, News is deselected, Pages are selected.

 

AI-Assisted User Experience

When AI is embedded directly into the application UI to give users a better user experience, as opposed to being accessed via the Joule window, we talk about ‚ÄúAI-Assisted User Experience‚Äù.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, we distinguish between AI base features and premium features:

  • Base features are free of charge, and only require that the customer signs the SAP AI Terms, which can be done via this link.
  • Premium features require SAP AI Units to be in place. Those listed here also require Joule Premium for Financial Management. Customers can activate this via SAP for Me -> Portfolio & Products -> Business AI.

The following are now generally available as premium features (they were both in beta testing with the 2508 release) and are described in more detail below:

  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications.
  • AI-assisted error explanation.

This feature is still in beta, but planned to become generally available with the 2602 release on March 12th:

  • AI-assisted situation handling.
    See below for more details.

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications

You could already use natural language and AI to personalize your My Home by adding Insights Cards, since the 2508 release. Now, with 2602, you can use natural language to find and add applications and insights tiles.

To do this, use the AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù in the salutation bar at the top of My Home, as shown at the top of Figure X. Clicking on this brings a pop-over with the option to add Insights Cards or, as shown, Apps & Insights Tiles. By describing what you want to do, the system will propose suitable applications and Insights Tiles. If you select them and click ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù, they will be added, either as an entry in your Apps Favorites section, or in the Insights Tiles section. Figure 13 shows these main steps.

Figure 13: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications. Alt Text: The image shows three screenshots: at the top an extract of My Home showing the blue salutation bar, with an AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù on the right. An arrow has been added linking it to the second screenshot, where a popover ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù is shown, where the user has entered ‚ÄúI want to monitor sales orders what app should I use to do this‚Äù, and two of four results are listed and visualized: ‚ÄúTrack Sales Orders‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Sales Orders‚Äù (shown as an insight tile). Below that a screenshot of the outcome in My Home: the former is added to Apps Favorites, the latter to Insights Tiles.

 Watch a demo:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:07 min.)

AI-Assisted Error Explanation

New users who are unfamiliar with the system may find that the short error messages give too little information for them to fully understand the issue, and what to do about it. This is where the Summarizing and Guiding and Recommending AI-patterns can help: the AI-Assisted Error Explanation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition uses these to summarize information which explains the error and provide a recommendation for how to resolve it. Figure 14 shows an example where a user has entered a Sold-to-Party ID which does not exist in the system.

Note that this feature is also only available for applications based on SAP Fiori elements.

Figure 14: AI-Assisted Error Explanation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502. Alt Text: On the left part of a data entry screen is shown, with the field ‚ÄúSold-to Party containing ‚ÄúABC‚Äù marked red and below that a  popover with an error message ‚ÄúNo customer master record exists for sold-to-party ABC‚Äù, and in the text line below that the AI icon followed by ‚ÄúGenerate Explanation‚Äù. A fat arrow leads from this text to the image on the right, which indicates what happens when you click on this text: you get a popover with an short Explanation section and a longer Resolution section with numbered actions.

Have a look:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Error Explanation (45 seconds)

AI-Assisted Situation Handling

The Intelligent Situation Handling framework helps users deal with not-so-frequent business situations, by notifying them of the situation, giving them an overview of the situation and providing contextual information to help resolve it. Ideally, the system also offers recommendations on how to go about resolving it.

Currently still in beta testing, we plan to make AI-assisted situation handling generally available with the 2602.1 release on March 12th.

Figure 15 shows what this looks like for a situation where a purchase contract is going to expire soon. The system is able to evaluate the company policy, in this case provided in the form of a decision matrix, and informs the user that a Request for Proposals is not needed for this contract, since its contract value is below the threshold.

Figure 15: AI-Assisted Situation Handling in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, showing how the user is notified in My Home and can navigate to the situation page and there generate a recommended solution. ALT Text: The To-Do card ‚ÄúThe purchase contract will expire soon‚Äù is shown at the top, with an arrow leading to the image below of the situation page, showing a ‚ÄúGeneral Info‚Äù section and a ‚ÄúRecommended Solution‚Äù section, which only contains the text ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt generated a solution yet. Would you like to do that now‚Äù, along with a ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù button with the AI icon. From there an arrow leads to the bottom image which shows the recommended solution text, along with thumbs-up and thumbs-down feedback buttons.

To see it in action, watch this:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Situation Handling in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:00 minutes).

The extended framework for Situation Handling allows customers to define their own situations. It is very powerful, but we have received feedback that it can be challenging for first time customers and partners to get it up and running. Hence Angelika Salmen has published this blog post to help you get started:

  • My First Situation with the Extended Framework.

For further information about Situation Handling, have a look at the links at the end of the above blog post. 

 

SAP Fiori elements mobile phone optimization

We have made significant improvements in the overall user experience for accessing selected applications from your mobile phone, with layouts and interactions tailored specifically for smartphones.

The recommended way to access SAP Fiori web applications from your mobile phone is via SAP Mobile Start, which treats web applications the same way as native mobile applications: users can define favorites, and see all their apps, both web and native mobile, in the Apps view.

The currently supported SAP Fiori elements based applications are now rendered in a more user-friendly way, reducing complexity for users on the go by removing non-essential features, patterns and services that are not suited for mobile use.

This results in improved productivity and speed with simplified navigation, faster access to actions and optimized information density.

The new layout is provided by the mobile mode. Users can switch on the previous desktop mode in case they need access to any of the non-essential features hidden in the mobile mode. Figure 16 shows an example of a list report in the desktop mode (on the left) and what it now looks like rendered in the mobile mode (on the right).

Figure 16: SAP Fiori elements mobile phone optimization. On the left a list report rendered using the previous desktop mode, on the right using the new mobile mode. Alt Text: screenshots of a list report as it would appear on a mobile phone. On the left with filter bar and filters visible, so that only one line of the list is shown; on the right they are hidden, so that three lines of content are shown.

Currently these five apps are supported:

  • My Home
  • Customer 360 View (F2187A)
  • Manage Direct Activity Allocation (F3697A)
  • Manage Material Serial Numbers (F6879)
  • Manage Production Supply Areas (F6935)
  • Serial Number History (F7368)

We are eager to learn from our customers to see how well the current functionality meets users real-life needs, and where we could improve the experience. If you are interested in trying this out and providing feedback, please sign up for our Early Adopter Care program.

 

UI Adaptation

Adapt UI is a key user extensibility tool for making no-code / low-code, upgrade-safe adaptations and extensions to SAP Fiori apps. We have continuously enhanced its scope, so that it now supports most of the common changes.

A key user is a business expert who is authorized to make changes on behalf of other users ‚Äì for example a team member who is interested in technology. The goal of key user extensibility is to empower business users to be able to adapt their working environment to suit their needs, without having to rely on system administrators.

Adapt UI is easy and safe to use: you can undo/redo changes, revert to a previously activated version or even revert to the original app.

Many Fiori apps contain object pages, that summarize information on a business object such as a sales order or a product. Adapt UI offers a large amount of options for adapting and extending object pages:

  • Hide/show SAP-defined fields
  • Add custom fields created with the SAP Fiori app Custom Fields (ID F1481)
  • Combine/split/rearrange/group/ungroup fields
  • Hide/show SAP-defined tabs, sections, tables, or action buttons
  • Change the configuration of tables (view settings, initial load, scrolling thresholds etc. ‚Äì as featured in my previous blog post)
  • Change text arrangement (ID only, Text first, Text las) ‚Äì also featured in my previous blog post.
  • Rename labels
  • Hide/show object header content
  • Embed web-based content in the object header or a section.

Key users who are authorized to use adapt UI can open it directly from their user menu in the launchpad. Once in started, Adapt UI shows you directly on the screen what changes you can make.

To find out more about this and watch a demo showing how it works and how easy it is, I thoroughly recommend this 13-minute video:

Video 1: Extending SAP Fiori Object Pages with Adapt UI. Click on the image to go to the video.The video shows you:

  • How to recognize an object page
  • What is Adapt UI
  • Prerequisites for Adapt UI
  • Demo
  • Tips for Working with Adapt UI
  • Key Takeaways
  • Resources worth knowing. These are:
    • SAP Design System - SAP Fiori: Object Page Floorplan
    • SAP Help - SAP Fiori Launchpad User Guide: ‚ÄãAdapting SAP Fiori UIs at Runtime ‚Äì Key User Adaptation.
    • SAP Learning - Tutorials: Key User Adaptation for SAPUI5 Applications.

Note that the video was created for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, so the transport step at the end is different in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì all the rest is relevant also for public edition, which is why I included it here.

The Adapt UI functionality is powered by SAPUI5 Flexibility technology.

 

Improvements in Details

User research has shown that it is easier to work with tables that contain hundreds of entries when the tables are implemented as a grid table rather than a responsive table.

Hence, with the 2602 release, we have looked at apps containing tables that typically have hundreds of entries and have changed the type of table used from a responsive table to a grid table.

For the full list of enhancements, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • UX in What‚Äôs New Viewer for  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602.

 

Continued soon with an overview of upcoming UX Innovations for Beta Testing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602

I hope you enjoyed this second part, covering what is now generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 and SAP Fiori launchpad. I will post part three in the next few days, covering exciting new UX innovations available for beta testing with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: New fixes and features in the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package with the Dec 2025 shipment
entry.content:
@alex_bundschuh ,

Thank you for sharing the detailed information about the new features planned for the pipeline step. We follow the SAP‚Äërecommended Design Guidelines during our build activities, and we've noticed that several pipeline iFlows are being flagged as non‚Äëcompliant with certain design rules.

One example is the guideline ‚ÄúDefine Identifiers to Search in Message Processing Logs‚Äù (SAP Note 3533030), which is reported as non‚Äëcompliant even though this validation can technically be skipped.

We would like to understand whether there is a roadmap for making the pipeline iFlows fully compliant with all design guidelines, or if certain rules will eventually be marked as Not Applicable for pipeline‚Äëdelivered content.

Thanks again for the transparency and updates. Let us know if there‚Äôs additional guidance we should follow.

3533030 - "Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs" in Design Guidelines is Non-Compliant - SAP for Me

entry.title: URL for custom logo
entry.content: I am trying to upload a custom logo in a Fiori application. It asks to put it via a URL. Currently I am using a sharepoint url from my personal account, this will make it visible to all internal SAP colleagues/teams. However, this app is going to be used by external customers, where can I upload my logo and use it's URL so that it is visible to all, internally as well externally?

entry.title: Re: Need to print the delivery document partner address i...
entry.content:
Good day @Naveen_Chiluveru 

Thank you for your question

What you see is in my opinion basically a clean core restriction.

However, a clean core alternative you may consider is the released Outbound Delivery API (A2X). This includes partner and partner address nodes. Which enables you to read BP. You can take this approach:

  • From your delivery document number, call API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY and read the delivery partners and identify the Carrier BP number. For more details, see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/588780cab2774a7ab9fffca3a7f919fe/2853a257ea0f4115a73af2a7ca2fd945.html?locale=en-US.
  • From the same API, read the Partner address entity for the carrier to get the address fields. See Operations for Outbound Delivery for more details.
  • Thereafter, use those fields in your custom Adobe form.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: My Home in SAP BTP ABAP Environment
entry.content:
Good news ‚Äì My Home is finally available with SAP BTP ABAP environment!

My Home is your personalized entry page that provides you with easy access to the business insights and applications you need to do your job with greater speed and agility. My Home for SAP BTP ABAP Environment lets you access and manage your favorite pages, your favorite apps, and your insights on any device. It follows a modular approach to meet the needs of different roles and builds on the functionality of the SAP Fiori launchpad using spaces and pages.

 

New Look and Feel

My Home will be set as default for newly provisioned and existing systems as of SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Accordingly, this soon changes the appearance of the SAP Fiori launchpad for every user. So, look forward to the new look and feel!

However, the setting to disable My Home will still be available for administrators until the release upgrade SAP BTP ABAP environment 2608. Then, My Home will be the one and only entry page within SAP BTP ABAP environment.

My Home in SAP BTP ABAP environment

 

 

My Home Sections

My Home is divided into different sections. You can view your News, Pages, Apps, Insights Tiles, and Insights Cards on this page.

 

News

The News section keeps you updated on your company's latest news, or SAP BTP ABAP environment system news.

News section on My Home entry page

 

Pages

The Pages section provides you with quick access to your favorite or most used pages. You can manage the visibility of your pages and order them in a way that enhances your productivity.  

Pages section on My Home entry page

 

Apps

The Apps section provides easy access to your favorite, most used, recently used, and recommended applications. The Apps section improves the discoverability of your applications. The Recommended tab offers app suggestions using SAP Business AI, based on your user-specific role assignment. You can add apps to the Favorites tab from your most used, recently used, and recommended applications. You can organize and categorize your favorite applications by using the grouping, ordering and color-coding functionality so you can access them even more efficiently. 

Apps section on My Home entry page

 

Insights Tiles and Insights Cards

The Insights section allows you to manage and monitor your company‚Äôs activities. It shows critical business information through KPIs and micro charts. This section is broken into two sections: Insights Tiles and Insights Cards. Insights cards and tiles display dynamic content at a glance. They provide quick and easy access to the applications that can provide more detailed information.

Insights tiles offer analytical information, such as charts or KPIs. Insights cards are similar to Insights tiles but provide more detailed analytical information in the form of charts, tables or lists from supporting overview page-, list report-, and analytical list page-based applications. Thanks to this information, you can assess what is happening at any time and take action when needed. You can customize the Insights section to display information that enables you to do your job with speed and agility. 

Insights section on My Home entry page

 

Make it Mine ‚Äì Personalize My Home to Your Needs

Following the ‚ÄúMake it Mine‚Äù approach, you can personalize the entry page to hide or display specific sections as well as the content maintained within these sections. Another key feature is the ability to customize the layout of these sections. This personalization capability allows you to prioritize the information that is most important to you. 

To personalize the entry page to your needs, choose My Home Settings from the dropdown menu of the respective sections. Here, you can customize the layout and configure the respective sections.

My Home Settings

 

We hope you enjoy working with My Home in SAP BTP ABAP environment and reap its benefits. You can look forward to more enhancements that will improve your My Home experience even further in future releases. Stay tuned for more updates!

entry.title: Re: Table maintenance generator position button question
entry.content:
In my opinion the solution by @striezl is not a work around. It is correct function to use if you want to filter the data.

The Position button is not filter button. It does what it says - it positions the table on the first record that has a key value that is equal to or higher than the entered key.

I agree it is not a good interface and it is surprising that SAP has not upgraded this for the last 40 years.

It is actually possible to modify the screen and many of the other components of the generated table maintenance.

The problem by this is that if you later need to change the table and re-generate the table maintenance, there is a risk that the modification will be overwritten and you must implement it again.

Her is an example where I have replaced the Position button with a Filter button (it simply calls the "Selection by content function): This is also not a brilliant gui, but it is a small fix that can be made in 5 minutes, so it is also very fast implemented if I later need to re-generate the table maintenance.






This is made as a screen modification - here:

Best regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: PR Re-Approval After Deletion
entry.content:
Good day @Keratiya_D 

Thank you for your question

The simple answer is NO.

The reason is, if PR is already approved, deleting the PR item would be treated by the system as a cancellation of that item and the system does not restart the approval workflow for that deleted item. See KBA 3555463 for more details.

I suggest you:

  • Cancel the approval item. In your Manage Purchase Requisitions Professional, open the PR and Edit. Select the item, then delete and save.

  • If you need a new approval after changes, this is only meaningful while your PR is still in approval. You can use Manage Conditions to Restart Workflow for PR changes. See KBA 2775709 for more insights.
  • If you truly need approval for cancellation of an already approved PR, this is not supported in public cloud workflow. You would need a custom governed process because standard PR workflow is not designed to restart after final approval for deletions. You can also read more on this in KBA 3555463.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Consolidated Error Messages in SAC Story Designer
entry.content:
An Efficiency Boost for SAC Story Designers: The New Consolidated Info Panel with the 2026.Q1 (2026.01) Release

Hello fellow SAC Story Designers,

Anyone who has already worked with the new "Model Repointing" feature knows how powerful it is. It offers enormous flexibility, but it also brings with it a challenge: after repointing a model, there is a significant risk that objects in the story will "break" - be it due to unmapped bindings, changed hierarchies, or other inconsistencies.

Previously, this meant one had to tediously navigate through every page and widget to re-establish confidence that the dashboard was in a proper, consumable state. This process was not only time-consuming but also prone to error.

For exactly this scenario, and similar ones, a decisive improvement has been introduced within the Story Design Time: the new, consolidated Info Panel. It is designed to become your central point of control for quality assurance.

The Old Way: Fragmented Information

Let us remember: Issues and recommendations were displayed in various places:

  • Critical errors (for example, a broken data binding) often appeared as individual toast messages or small icons on the widget itself.
  • Performance recommendations were somewhat hidden in a separate popup or in tooltips.

The result was a fragmented overview where one had to actively hunt for problems and could easily miss something.

The New Way: One Panel for Everything

The new Info Panel, which you can access via the icon in the top toolbar, breaks with this fragmentation. It consolidates all relevant messages in one location, giving you a clear and immediate overview of your story's health.

 

Caption: The new, consolidated Info Panel with its 'Issues', 'Performance Recommendations', and 'Scripting Errors' tabs.

Let us look at the decisive improvements in more detail:

The "Issues" Tab: The New Core Component

The most important new area is the "Issues" tab. Here, all asset-related problems are centrally collected and intelligently structured:

  • Clear Categorization: The messages can be filtered by severity (Error, Warning, Info) and are color-coded, so you see immediately what is critical.
  • Logical Structure: The list is grouped hierarchically by page and widget. You can see at a glance which chart on which page is affected.

Typical issues that you will find here are, for example:

  • Missing Input Control: A control element was deleted that is required by a chart.
  • Invalid Calculation: A calculation is no longer valid because it depends on another, missing calculation.

Integrated Performance and Scripting Insights

Next to the "Issues" tab, you find the familiar sections, which are now, however, seamlessly integrated:

  • Performance Recommendations: The proactive tips for optimizing widget performance are now also part of this central panel. Consequently, you have performance and functional issues in one view. Please check also our separate blogpost on this topic SAP Business Data Cloud - Performance Recommendations for Story Designers
  • Scripting Errors: For all who work in "Advanced Mode," scripting errors are also consolidated here, which simplifies the debugging of complex interactions considerably.

The Concrete Value for Your Daily Workflow

  • Security after Model Repointing: Instead of a manual search, you simply open the Info Panel and receive a complete list of all problems that resulted from the repointing.
  • Significant Time Savings in Debugging: The direct action links ("Open Builder Panel") reduce the click paths and search effort to a minimum.
  • Increased Story Quality: You will no longer overlook warnings or "smaller" problems and can therefore ensure a consistently high quality of your dashboards.
  • A More Efficient Workflow: All information relevant to the story's health is bundled in one place. No more jumping between different menus and views is necessary.

Conclusion

The new, consolidated Info Panel is more than just a cosmetic update. It is a fundamentally improved tool that directly addresses the pain points of us, the story designers. It proves its value especially in scenarios like Model Repointing, by helping us to quickly and reliably maintain control over complex stories.

It is a small but highly effective step towards a cleaner and more efficient design process.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation
entry.content:
Targeted Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation with the 2026.Q1 (2026.02) Release

Hello everyone,

As many of you know, a significant technical transition is on the horizon for SAP Analytics Cloud: with the Q2 2026 release, "Classic Stories" will be officially deprecated. From this point on, it will no longer be possible to open or edit stories based on the old stack. The path forward is the conversion of this content to the "Optimized Story" format.

To support you in this process, we have previously provided tools that identify which Classic Stories are still actively in use. This approach of targeted conversion has helped many of you to set priorities (you can read more about this in our blog post on Efficient Migration of SAC Classic Stories: Focusing on the Essentials).

However, based on your feedback, we are now taking this a significant step further. Instead of just focusing on stories that are in use, we're now giving you the tools to get a complete overview and proactively clean up your system.

What's New? Three Key Enhancements for Your System Management

To make the transition as smooth as possible, we have specifically enhanced three areas of SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. A Complete, Exportable List of All Classic Stories

In the System > Overview > Content area, you will now find a new, comprehensive table. This table lists all Classic Stories present in your system‚Äîregardless of whether they have been used recently or not. The key advantage: this list is fully exportable. You can easily load the data into Excel or another tool to sort, filter, and align with business departments.

2. Targeted Deletion of Classic Stories in Housekeeping

A clean system is a performant system. We have enhanced the System > Overview > Housekeeping area to allow you to specifically filter for Classic Stories and delete them directly, even in bulk. This builds upon the existing housekeeping functionalities and provides you with a powerful tool for system hygiene. (For a general introduction to this topic, you can refer to our Efficient Data Maintenance in SAP Analytics Cloud System Overview - Housekeeping.)

 

 

3. Enhanced Metadata for Custom Analyses

For those who want to perform deeper analyses or build their own monitoring dashboards, we have enhanced the underlying data model, known as the 'Resource' model. This model is part of the standard monitoring content that is automatically updated with every system update. You can find this content under the path Files > System > Common > SAC Content.

Our recommendation is to use the standard dashboards provided there to track the progress of your migration efforts.

However, if you wish to build your own analyses or tables to specifically list Classic Stories, you can do so directly on the 'Resource' data model. To get a precise list, apply the following filters to the data source:

  • Resource Version: CLASSIC
  • Object Type: STORY
  • Resource Subtype: (No Value)

 

These filters ensure that you are exclusively looking at Classic Stories and not other object types or subtypes, such as bookmarks, in your analysis.

A Recommended Workflow

  1. Inventory: Export the complete list of Classic Stories from the System > Overview > Content area.
  2. Analysis & Decision: Go through the list and classify each story: Convert or Delete?
  3. Execution:
    1. Convert the necessary stories to the Optimized Story experience.
    2. Use the new feature in Housekeeping to remove the obsolete stories.
  4. Monitoring: Keep track of your progress, either with the standard content found under Files > System > Common > SAC Content or with your own custom analysis.

Summary

The Q2 2026 deadline is set. With a complete overview, targeted deletion capabilities, and enhanced metadata, you now have full control over the process. We recommend starting to familiarize yourself with these new tools early to ensure a smooth transition and to start the future with a clean system.

entry.title: Re: Data category : Dimension vs Cube
entry.content:
Hello,

Your question is very broad, so I'll only be able to give a broad answer. 

In general, a "Fact" view is a view that contains transactional data. 
Think things like "Sales", "Orders" and so on. 
You have some columns, and you have a number:

Profit CenterMATERIALQUANTITY SOLD
1000000110
1000000220

A dimension on the other hand, are each of the column, that contain any other information: In this case, "MATERIAL" and "Profit Center" are your dimensions.

Even though you might not be working with CDS views, I think the general documentation might be helpful:

Dimension Views | SAP Help Portal
Fact Views | SAP Help Portal

So. If your view is based on a tables that contain transactions: Fact.
Each column in that fact view is potentially: Dimension.

entry.title: Re: Management of Mold Manufacturing
entry.content:
Explore the below recommended approaches

1. Project System (PS) + Investment Management
Treat the mold as an internal project (WBS element). Assign all raw materials and subcontracting services to the WBS. Use network activities to represent subcontracting stages. This way, you can track costs, materials issued, and services received against the project until capitalization. At completion, settle the WBS to an Asset Under Construction (AuC), then capitalize to the fixed asset.

2. Special Stock for Subcontractor (Stock Type O)
SAP allows you to manage customer or subcontractor stock separately. You can issue raw materials to subcontractor stock (movement type 541) and track them until the mold returns. This gives you visibility of inventory physically at the subcontractor site without creating new material codes.

3. Combination: PS + Subcontractor Stock
Use PS/WBS for overall mold investment tracking. Use subcontractor stock for material visibility. Costs of subcontracting services are posted to the WBS, while materials are tracked in stock type O. When the mold is received, you settle the WBS to the fixed asset.

4. Avoiding Excess Material Masters
Instead of creating a new material code for each mold, treat the mold as a project/asset, not a material. Only maintain material masters for raw materials and standard components. The mold itself is created directly as an asset master record once complete.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on SLD Parameters for Managed System Se...
entry.content:
Hello team,

Refer to below documentation:

2729787 - FAQ: SAP HANA Data Supplier for System Landscape Directory (SLD), Solution Manager and Focused Run (FRUN)

B) You have no HSR scenario configured:

You configured on your HANA system:

nameserver.ini
[SLD]
enable_virtdbhome = true

but you did not configure the depending parameters in

global.ini
[system_landscape_hostname_virtualization]
#sldvirtdbhome    =
#sldsystemhome  =

To solve the issue, disable the parameter for virtual host name usage

nameserver.ini
[SLD]
enable_virtdbhome = false

 

Configuring an SAP HANA System to Connect to the System Landscape Directory (SLD)

______________________________________________________________________________ 

Thanks and best regards,
Luis Salazar
SAP Technical Support - ALM

entry.title: Re: Person ID to User ID Synchronisation to be Avoided du...
entry.content:
Hi bbknrt,

The User ID is the system‚Äôs unique identifier for an employment record and, for EC customers, it is hardcoded mapped to the Personal ID External at the time of initial hire.

In cases of multiple employments, such as when a Concurrent Employment or Global Assignment is added, the system automatically generates the User ID for this second employment, while the Personal ID External remains unchanged. This User ID is generated based on the ‚ÄúNext Person ID Assigned‚Äù value configured in Company, System and Logo Settings.

In summary, it is not possible to define a different User ID for EC new hires, as the User ID is hardcoded mapped to the Personal ID External.

I hope this helps!

Thank you.

Best Regards,

Karen Perez

  2. Has an outbound delivery been created only for the first line item, or was there any partial delivery attempt for the second or third?
  3. You mention the second and third items are ‚Äúnot confirmed.‚Äù Do they have confirmed quantities in ATP or are they completely unconfirmed?
  4. Is the item category TAN set up in customizing to allow changes to TAB, and is this setting identical for all three items?
  5. You note delivery priority is editable for both items. Is this field editable because no delivery exists yet, or is there a difference in schedule line status?
  6. For the third line item, is the item category field greyed out, or does it throw an error when you attempt to change it?
  7. Are there any differences in material master, schedule line category, or requirements class between the second and third items?

entry.title: Re: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi, @albertosimeoni 

Unfortunately, you are correct: my idea is about how to trigger ABAP code execution, but not about how to transfer data from Datasphere to AS ABAP.üôÅ    Inability to use parameters is a severe restriction.    

Your second question "the source to be extracted is the output of an ABAP report" is slightly simpler. This is exactly my case. I have an ABAP report that filling a custom Z-table with calculation results. I created two flows.

First data flow is OData-based, as I described in blog. And I use "SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN" in my CALCULATE method.

Then I created a replication flow, based on usual connection of type 'SAP S/4HANA On-Premise'. This flow simply a load of data from Z-table  into Datasphere.

Finally, I made a task chain from these two flows. When chain run starting, first flow triggering my program and waiting for calculation finish (due to 'AND RETURN' addition. When program results ready and written to Z-table, first flow finis and task chain call second flow to replicate prepared data into Datasphere.

entry.title: Re: How do I maintain a warranty period for a material as...
entry.content:
Below are the recommended solution

  • Maintain warranty templates in customizing with validity periods (e.g., 12 months, 24 months).
  • Assign templates to materials (or material groups) so they are automatically inherited when equipment is created.
  • Use sales org/market logic to differentiate warranty templates if periods vary by region.
  • Ensure the start date is set automatically from delivery or installation, so users don‚Äôt need to enter it manually.

entry.title: Re: Cost Center changes for employee and active Customer...
entry.content:
When an employee switches cost centers within the same company code, the impact depends on how the project is set up and how costs are captured:

What happens in standard SAP is existing postings (time confirmations, expenses, activity allocations) remain with the old cost center. They are historical records and are not automatically re‚Äëassigned. Future postings (after the organizational change) will flow to the new cost center once the employee‚Äôs master data (HR assignment or activity type allocation) is updated. The project itself doesn‚Äôt automatically update to reflect the new cost center; it continues to show the old one for past postings.

The Best Practice is

  • Keep history intact (don‚Äôt change past postings).
  • Update project master data for responsibility and future postings.
  • Only repost costs if reporting or controlling requirements demand it.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q4 2025: Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q4, we rolled out AI-powered enhancements for SAP UI5 development, digital experiences, and SAP Mobile Start, along with improved operational control and visibility for automating business processes. Most significantly, the agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available, empowering developers to build custom Joule agents.

Check out our Top 10 Q4 2025 Release Highlights!

 

Enhancements and AI-Powered Development

AI-guided development for building agents in Joule Studio.

 1. Building custom agents with Joule Studio

Now generally available, the agent builder in Joule Studio lets developers create custom Joule agents using natural language, Model Context Protocol (MCP) enabled integrations, multi-agent orchestration, and existing SAP Build content. With this capability, you can build scalable, production-grade agents designed to deliver real business impact across your enterprise.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

2. AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

Joule is now integrated across all SAP Build Work Zone editions, helping employees navigate complex workflows within their digital workspace using natural language queries. With context-aware answers, content generation, and proactive insights, Joule helps teams work more productively.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

3. Enhanced AI support for SAPUI5 development

With the new /ui5-create-app slash command in Joule for SAP Build Code, developers can now generate freestyle UI5 applications. The AI assistant/Joule guides the conversation, producing a ready-to-use, best-practice app as a starting point. This streamlines development, reduces setup effort, and helps teams follow consistent UI5 standards from the very beginning.
Learn more in this blog post.

How the AI-supported freestyle SAPUI5 app generation works. Learn more in this blog post.

 

4. Define status flows in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)

The new status flow feature in CAP lets developers define application workflows with minimal effort using just three CDS annotations. With @flow.status, @from, and @TO, developers can mark status properties and define transitions, while the system automatically generates the necessary handlers and UI annotations. This reduces manual coding, provides a robust framework, and still allows developers complete control to override and customize the generated logic.
Learn more in the guide.

 

 

Enhanced Operational Control and Automation

5. Streamline migration to SAP Build Process Automation

With the ‚ÄúNo Correlation‚Äù feature in Process Visibility, organizations can smoothly transition from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation. This feature enables tracking of legacy and new processes in a single, unified view without data duplication or reporting disruptions, helping organizations modernize their operations while maintaining visibility, accuracy, and performance.
Learn more in this blog post.

 

6. Expanded functionality for process automation

  • Template-based notifications: You can now compose template-based notifications using HTML as part of your process logic, enabling teams to design more flexible e-mails that fit complex business scenarios.

    Learn more.
  • Preserve and combine results for Decision Tables: Decision Tables in process automation now support aggregating and preserving outputs from multiple tables. With the new append operation, users can accumulate results across multiple rule evaluations, enabling richer decision outcomes.  
    Learn more    .

    When opening an existing decision that uses list-type results, users will see a banner notification indicating that the behaviour has changed.

    If the user clicks on ‚ÄúUpdate Decision Table Behavior‚Äù, the user gets to select to continue with the existing behavior or choose the new behavior to append the content to the result.
  • Enable or disable individual Decision rules: While modeling decisions in process automation, you can now activate or deactivate individual rules based on business requirements. The deactivated rules are skipped during execution but remain accessible, providing greater control of Decision artifacts.

    Learn more.
  • Manage workflow tasks in process automation: Workflow monitoring applications now support assigning tasks to a group, improving flexibility and reducing manual effort. Administrators can search for users or groups, reassign running workflow instances, and receive clear confirmation or error messages, ensuring business continuity.

    Learn more.

 

7. Expanded trigger options for SAP Build Process Automation

SAP Build Process Automation now offers enhanced trigger options that enable scalable automation across SAP and non-SAP systems:

  • Queue triggers to start a process: These triggers leverage UiPath Queue Management to start SAP Build Process Automation processes automatically, enabling the smooth automation of repetitive tasks. Learn more.
  • UiPath connector triggers: These event-driven triggers powered by UiPath Integration Service enable automation across non-SAP systems, providing real-time responsiveness to critical business activities with minimal configuration effort. Learn more.

 

Digital Experience & Mobile Start Innovations

8. Enhanced user experience for mobile and desktop in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition now provides a coherent and intuitive navigation model across desktop browsers and SAP Mobile Start. Employees can quickly access the apps and business content they need on the go through structured spaces and pages. By organizing content into logical workspaces, essential tools open in seconds, reducing operational friction, minimizing errors, and enabling users to stay productive while moving between tasks.
Learn more in the Help Portal.

 

9. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start adopts Apple's new Liquid Glass design language released with iOS 26.

SAP Mobile Start continues to elevate the mobile experience for end-users with several new features that improve usability, efficiency, and visual design:

  • Adoption of Apple‚Äôs Liquid Glass design: SAP Mobile Start now incorporates Apple‚Äôs new Liquid Glass design language introduced with iOS 16. This provides a more dynamic user experience and increases screen space as the navigation bar collapses when not needed.
  • Additional To-Do filter option ‚ÄúGroup‚Äù: End-users can now filter their To-Dos by semantic groups defined in Task Center, making it easier to organize and prioritize tasks.
  • New compact list view for To-Dos: To-Dos can now be displayed in a more compact list view instead of the traditional cards view, allowing users to see more items at a glance and manage tasks more efficiently.

Learn more in the latest blog post.

 

10. Expanded content capacity in SAP Build Work Zone sites

SAP Build Work Zone sites can now host thousands of documents and translations without technical limits. This lets administrators build richer site architecture that supports multiple regions and languages while keeping content organized, giving employees faster access to a comprehensive and well-structured digital workplace.

 

 

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Webinar on February 5th as we explore building custom agents with Joule Studio, AI support for SAPUI5, and more!

 

Choose your session:

üïò9:00 AM - 10:00 AM CET ‚Üí https://url.sap/al5xcu

 üïì 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM CET ‚Üí https://url.sap/egqfui
